awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The fingerprint of abrupt temperature events throughout Greenland during the last glacial period
awd_abstract_narration:
The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (or AMOC) is an important part of the global three-dimensional ocean circulation (global ocean conveyor belt) that includes the well-known, northward-flowing Gulf Stream current that redistributes heat and thereby affects climate. The AMOC is expected to weaken or even collapse in the coming centuries, with several recent studies suggesting that this weakening has already begun. The AMOC collapse would not only severely impact climate in the North Atlantic region but would also weaken the monsoon rains that a large portion of the global population depends on for their livelihood. Studying ice cores can shed light on past changes in the strength of the AMOC and can help scientists better understand the stability and behavior of this important ocean circulation system. Greenland ice cores and ocean sediment records show that during the last Ice Age (100,000 to 20,000 years ago) the AMOC repeatedly collapsed and restarted, resulting in a series of extreme climate oscillations commonly known as Dansgaard-Oeschger (D-O) cycles. Each D-O event consists of an abrupt (decadal-scale) warming episode (increase of 8-15 degrees Centigrade) observed in Greenland ice cores, leading to a few millennia of warmer climate followed by a gradual cooling back to full glacial conditions. The proposed research will develop temperature records from two Greenland ice cores to determine both the geographic distribution as well as the intensity of the D-O events throughout Greenland. These records will provide a spatial ?fingerprint? of the D-O events, which can be used a forensic tool to determine the location of D-O warming and the migration of the sea-ice edge around Greenland during these events. These data will be included in climate simulations using state-of-the-art global climate models to improve our understanding of the physical nature of these enigmatic events. The research will contribute to reliable timescales for the two ice cores, with benefits to the wider ice core community. The work will support an early-career scientist and a graduate student and will also provide outreach to public schools. 

Understanding the physical processes that drive the Earth?s climate system throughout a Dansgaard-Oeschger (D-O) event remains an important open scientific question in paleoclimate research. The spatial pattern of D-O warming holds clues to the origin of D-O events, in particular whether the critical geographic area is located in the Labrador Sea or in the GIN (Greenland, Iceland, Norwegian) seas. Ultra-high-resolution stable isotope records from these ice cores document changes in the hydrological cycle associated with these abrupt warming episodes. Climate models show that the southern Dye-3 ice core is more sensitive to abrupt climate change than previously analyzed ice cores, giving the possibility of observing for the first time the temperature imprint of a Heinrich event (a natural phenomenon in which large armadas of icebergs break off from glaciers and traverse the North Atlantic Ocean), as well as the largest D-O warmings ever observed. Isotope enabled climate model simulations will provide improved interpretation of changes in second-order isotope parameters (deuterium- and 17O excess) through D-O and Heinrich-events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Evidence from Earth's recent geologic past suggests that our climate exhibits tipping points: critical thresholds that, when exceeded, result in abrupt, irreversible and potentially catastrophic change. Understanding such tipping points is therefore of both societal and scientific importance. Of these critical systems, the Dansgaard-Oeschger (D-O) cycle is one of the most well-studied examples. This cycle is active only during Ice Ages, the most recent of which occurred between 120,000 and 12,000 years before present. The D-O cycle is composed of a series of alternating warm and cold periods in the circum-North Atlantic region, each of which lasted hundreds to tens of thousands of years. The transitions between these stages were abrupt, and occurred on a timescale of mere decades. Changes to the major currents of the Atlantic Ocean were responsible for these large climate oscillations, with North Atlantic sea ice playing a major role also.

Greenland is positioned centrally in the North Atlantic, and therefore Greenland ice cores can provide unique insights into Dansgaard-Oeschger events and their dynamics. The objective of this project is to generate new observational records from Greenland ice cores, and combine these with existing data to create a Greenland-wide "fingerprint" of a D-O event, that can be used to infer the climate dynamics of these events and identify key locations of sea ice change.

The project performed new measurements in two Greenland ice cores. The first is the Dye 3 core, which was drilled in the 1980s. Ice from this core was re-analyzed it with state-of-the art modern techniques. The second core is the East Greenland Ice-core Project (EGRIP), which finished drilling in 2023 after experiencing delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic. For both cores, we performed measurements of the water stable isotope ratios using a continuous flow analysis technique, and measurements of the stable isotope composition of atmospheric N2. The former provides a proxy for vapor transport pathways to Greenland; the latter reflects thermal gradients in the snowpack on top of the ice sheet, and allows for the most accurate reconstruction of abrupt surface temperature change. To interpret the N2 isotope data, the project involved model simulations the past densification of the firn layer - the ~60 m thick perennial snow pack that covers the ice sheet.

The final product is a detailed and extensive database of the spatial impact of abrupt Dansgaard-Oeschger events on Greenland climate. The database includes seven Greenland ice cores, which together provide good spatial coverage of the island. The database compiles data for the D-O impact on four climate parameters: (i) the site temperature as derived from N2 isotopes, (ii) the water isotope 18O/16O ratio, or δ18O, a proxy for site temperature and a tracer of vapor origin, (iii) the water isotope deuterium excess, a proxy for vapor source conditions and vapor pathways, and (iv) the rate of snowfall. Together, these data provide a detailed picture of the impact of D-O events on Greenland that can be used to benchmark climate models that seek to simulate these events.

Comparing the database to existing D-O simulations by isotope-enabled climate models shows that these models have considerable skill in capturing the Greenland impact of these events. We use a series of idealized experiments in an isotope-enabled atmosphere model where we modify sea ice conditions in various parts of the North Atlantic, to see which changes best explain our multi-proxy database. We find that wintertime sea ice in the North Atlantic Subpolar Gyre best explains the observational data. This contrast with the common notion found in the literature that the Nordic Seas are the main location of D-O sea ice activity. Moisture tagging in these model simulations further suggests that changes to the vapor source distribution can explain almost the entire change in water stable isotope ratios observed in Greenland ice cores. This contradicts the traditional interpretation of this proxy, which suggests that the water isotope ratio reflects the site temperature via so-called Rayleigh distillation along the vapor pathway.

The new database of the spatial fingerprint of Dansgaard-Oeschger events on Greenland climate enables the testing of climate models and hypotheses regarding event dynamics. The project uses the database to derive new insights about the important and profound D-O climate oscillations.

The award provided support for a graduate student at Oregon State University, who included the work in their PhD thesis. The student gained experience in performing state-of-the-art climate model simulations. The project further supported summer support for an international visiting student, providing them with a valuable research experience. In these ways, the project contributed to educating the STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) workforce. For the duration of the project researchers visited local middle schools to provide polar science education reaching around 300 students annually, and on a regular basis provided laboratory tours and lectures to members of the public.
